title: The Knoll
author: Philip J. LaMantia
summary:

Whose greasy fingers seek control...
content:
There lives a man atop the Knoll,
Whose greasy fingers seek control;
As days go past, the man yearns for more,
Leaving his home to wander and spread his spores.

In villages he finds the ones in need,
And offering kind help, he plants the seed.
Then they find in their homes a creeping hold
A plant, a vine, a spore becoming mold.

The man returns to his forested abode,
Seeking some comfort, he finds his sickly toad.
The toad cries out, “Now let me go, I plea;
No longer do I want this grassbed home for me!”
The man grows angry and rumples at its nose;
Thus, the toad falls silent, working on its prose.

The Knoll seeks more its grasses growing hungry;
The man feeds it each day with gathered twigs dumbly.
It rumbles loud as colder nights draw near;
So he lies down with it and calls it dear.
The toad then creaks a ribbit filled with fear,
“Please, I implore you now; O lend your ear.
The Knoll is feeding on your lonely mind;
Go to the village, step outside.
In your absence I shall cleanse your home;
The Knoll will shrink, becoming a clean biome.”

The man then laughed at toad’s simple plea;
He knew the Knoll was the worst of any flea.
Yet left the home in hopes the toad was right
That such a creature small could mount a fight.
The days passed on; the toad stayed locked within,
Its throat clogged thick by workings of the Djinn.
Yet it prevailed though nearing its last breath
The Knoll now clean and void of the lethe.

As toad drifted to sleep, the man returned,
Holding a pot with brand new fronds newly un-fern’d.
Though frog had tried, the man contained the stain
A piece of Knoll embedded deep in his brain.
Thus fern took hold and gave the Knoll a path back;
The toad cried out, its lungs burst with spore-filled sacs.

title: A Squire and a Knight
author: Philip J. LaMantia
summary:

The Knight, worn thin, still carried steady flame.
The squire watched him, light as a feather...
content:
Squire and Knight rode miles together.
The Knight, worn thin, still carried steady flame.
The squire watched him, light as a feather.
“Where do we ride today?", the squire asked.
“My final place. The ground that bears my name.”

The squire shrieked in fear, his master now departing.
“Who will I learn from whence you are gone?
Still full of wisdom left for imparting.
Let me die first, for the world will not miss me.”
“It will, for it is your time to be called-on”

“Then, it is not your teachings but your amity
I require. Watch me live as you taught,
So I don't suffer grave calamity.”
A crow landed on the middle road.
“I want nothing more. For this I am wrought.”

“Who will find me when I am lost and scared?
Or pick me up and guide my way back home?
There is more I need, I am lost, Impaired!”
The Knight looked stoically straight ahead.
“Fear not, for your heart bears my final tome.”

title: Economic Report on the effect of Active Income Residence Programs in Calabria
